Scoring and prioritising leads in a small aviation business does not require a big, expensive CRM system. In fact, many flying clubs, flight schools, charter operators, and maintenance organisations already have most of the data they need. It is usually just scattered across inboxes, forms, spreadsheets, and booking tools.

Lead scoring simply means deciding which enquiries deserve attention first, and which ones can wait or be handled automatically. When done well, it reduces response time for high value prospects, avoids wasting time on poor fits, and creates a calmer, more predictable sales and onboarding process.

Why lead scoring matters in aviation

Aviation businesses deal with very different types of leads. A student pilot asking about trial flights is very different from an operator enquiring about block charter hours, or an aircraft owner asking for long term maintenance support. Treating every enquiry the same leads to rushed decisions, missed follow ups, and constant interruptions.

Lead scoring gives structure to this. Even a simple system helps you answer three questions immediately:
Who should I respond to first?
What kind of response do they need?
What should happen next if I do not respond right away?

Starting simple without a CRM

You do not need Salesforce or HubSpot for this. Many aviation SMBs start with nothing more than:
An online enquiry form
An email inbox
A spreadsheet or lightweight database
An automation tool such as Make

The key is capturing a few useful signals when someone first gets in touch. For example:
Type of enquiry (training, charter, maintenance, membership)
Urgency (immediate, this month, just researching)
Budget or aircraft type
How they found you
Whether they have flown before or own an aircraft

Each of these can contribute to a basic score.

An example for a flight school

Imagine a flight school with an online contact form. You ask:
Are you looking for a trial flight, licence training, or advanced ratings?
When would you like to start?
Have you flown before?

Behind the scenes, you can assign simple values:
Advanced ratings enquiry = high score
Start within 30 days = high score
Previous flying experience = medium score

Using Make, you can automatically:
Receive the form submission
Calculate a total score based on answers
Tag the lead as High, Medium, or Low priority
Store it in a Google Sheet or Airtable
Send a tailored reply

High priority leads get a personal email with availability and a phone call reminder sent to your team. Medium priority leads get a helpful information pack and an invitation to book a call. Low priority leads get an automated welcome email and are added to a follow up sequence that checks in after a week or two.

No CRM required, but the behaviour is the same as professional sales systems.

Charter and aircraft services use case

For charter operators or maintenance organisations, lead scoring is often about aircraft size, scope, and seriousness.

An enquiry mentioning urgent AOG support, turbine aircraft, or recurring charter work should not sit in the same queue as a vague availability question.

You can score based on:
Aircraft type
Location
Urgency
Mention of contracts or ongoing work
Out of hours request

Automation can then route high scoring leads to immediate notifications via email or internal messaging, while lower scoring enquiries receive an acknowledgement and are processed during normal business hours.

This alone reduces stress on staff and ensures valuable opportunities are handled promptly.

Using simple tools you may already have

Many aviation businesses already use:
Google Forms or website forms
Shared inboxes
Scheduling tools
Accounting or booking software

Make can connect these without changing your core systems. For example:
Website form submission triggers a scoring scenario
Scores and notes are written into a spreadsheet
The spreadsheet update triggers different email templates
Calendar reminders are created for follow ups
A summary is sent to the owner or ops manager once per day

The result is a quiet, orderly flow of information instead of reactive inbox checking.

Gradually adding more intelligence

Once the basics are working, you can layer on more advanced logic:
Increase lead score if they open emails or book a call
Decrease score if there is no response after multiple follow ups
Route certain lead types directly into booking workflows
Sync high quality leads into a lightweight CRM or customer database
Generate reports that show enquiry quality by source

For flying clubs, this can help identify which marketing activities attract committed members rather than casual browsers. For schools, it clarifies which channels produce students who actually start training. For maintenance shops, it highlights repeat aircraft owners vs one off requests.

The real benefit: less noise, better focus

Lead scoring is not about pushing sales harder. It is about protecting your time and your team‚Äôs attention. In aviation, interruptions cost more than just efficiency. They affect safety culture, customer perception, and staff workload.

By letting automation handle sorting, tagging, and responding to enquiries, you create space for human judgement where it matters most: building relationships, planning operations, and delivering safe, high quality service.

If you are feeling overwhelmed by enquiries but know not all of them deserve the same effort, lead scoring is one of the highest leverage automations you can implement. Start small, keep it simple, and let the system grow with your business.

5 Key Reasons to Invest in Software;

1. Software has become the operational core of companies
It is no longer a support function, but a critical infrastructure (ERP, CRM, data, security, workflow). Replacing these systems is expensive, risky and time-consuming, which creates high switching costs and stable revenues.

2. AI enhances the value of the best platforms, not displaces them
2024-2025 showed that AI does not destroy SaaS, but rewards platforms with proprietary data, distribution and integration into workflows. Providers that build AI into the core product win.

3. Structural productivity growth is now measurable
Companies are actually achieving more with fewer employees. Software is the main channel for monetizing this productivity, which supports IT budgets in the long term even in a slower macro environment.

4. High free cash flow and scalability
The best software companies generate 25-40% free cash flow, have low marginal costs and global scalability, which makes them resilient to inflation and capital disciplined.

5. Geopolitical and cyber realities increase demand
Fragmentation of the world, data regulation and the growth of cyber threats increase the strategic importance of software (security, compliance, data governance), which creates long-term, non-cyclical demand.

Software is no longer a ‚Äúbet on growth‚Äù, but a strategic allocation of capital into the digital infrastructure of the modern economy. Artificial intelligence is a catalyst, not a threat; the quality of the platform, data and cash flows is becoming decisive.
